awd_titl_txt: MRI-Consortium:  Acquisition of an advanced mass spectrometer
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the Institute for Systems Biology (ISB) to support the purchase of an advanced mass spectrometry (MS) instrument.  Mass spectrometry is used by researchers to catalogue and quantify many variants of the protein complement of an organism or organelle system and to measure other metabolites.    Researchers at the ISB will extend their previous work with advanced detectors, software and lab protocols to improve protein and metabolite profiling in biological samples.  Through training of researchers directly or attending expert courses given regularly at ISB, this project will enhance the teaching, training and learning by providing innovative tools to maintain the cutting-edge curriculum of these courses from PhD students, post-docs to experienced PIs. The ISB award-winning high school education program will also support inquiry-based teaching practices at the grassroots. Students and teachers of underrepresented groups will collaborate with scientists to bring current science  concepts and practices into high school classrooms.  

The new MS instrument will provide enhanced capabilities of comprehensive high-throughput discovery and targeted analyses, characterization of post-translational modifications, and protein interaction analysis. Using knowledge gained from previous research efforts, as well as computational tools for prediction and spectral interpretation, the ISB researchers will provide new insights into multiple biochemical events such as transcription/translation interplay, organelle biogenesis, metabolic network analysis, novel capture and quantitation reagent development and their applications. The new system will complement the computational expertise in proteomics hardware and software development capabilities among ISB researchers to advance many other projects.  The use of data independent analysis (DIA) with this instrument and interrogation through new software tools for data analysis will provide users unprecedented capabilities in molecular ion identification and quantitation. Results from the studies will be published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at regional and national scientific meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Protein analysis is essential for the elucidation of biological process governing a living body. As the genome of each cell dictates the makeup of that cell, it is the proteins that are encoded by that genome that carry out the molecular functions of life. The structure of proteins dictates their function and understanding how these functions are carried out is the essence of systems biology, the art of reducing each function to a defined system and relating these systems as parts of a layered system as in typical engineering. To understand the system, one needs to understand each part and have the tools to identify each part in the system. For proteins, the most versatile technology to identify, quantify and define changes to each protein is called mass spectrometry. As mass spectrometry continues to evolve and allow multitudes of protein measurements per hour, new, faster and more versatile mass spectrometers are needed to understand the infinite complexity of a living cell.

The outcomes of this project were to acquire a new Bruker timsTOF Pro dual-TIMS analyzer Mass Spectrometry (MS) system for cutting-edge proteomics analysis, and to maintain technical capabilities and relevance in protein biology and proteomics across a number of NSF projects and related programs in order to provide the best possible technology for users and for students to train with. Our users, trainees and students will gain benefit from this new technological advance by providing cutting-edge technology and supply years of service to numerous protein-centric biology programs. The Bruker timsTOF Pro dual-TIMS analyzer MS system represents a unique high-resolution mass spectrometry, yielding comparable superior performance in ion fractionation, fragmentation and accumulation beyond any other instrument on the market. The use of ion mobility separation results in improved signal-to-noise ratios with high-efficiency technology. The advanced capabilities of this instrument will provide unparalleled analysis capability for users to define proteomes and their modifications important in biological function at far greater depths than ever realized with prior instrumentation. The instrument will be applied to proteins and metabolites of interest in the array of projects described in the original proposal as well as many other projects proposed in the fullness of time from other interested users. In addition, as new students are present and are taught in the use of mass spectrometry in this post-COVID era, we will have cutting-edge equipment for them to use and learn from so that these students will have access to the latest technology available as we prepare them to become independent researchers.

 


Last Modified: 02/19/2023
Modified by: Robert Moritz
